title: Sheffield Shield 2019: Tim Paine century, 13-year drought, Test captain, Steve Smith
text:
Cricket: Pat Cummins says criticism of Aussie captain Tim Paine is 'unfair' after leading the side to a 2-2 Ashes retaining draw in England.

Australian Test captain Tim Paine has let his bat do the talking after claims his time in the national set up were numbered.

Paine, who became the first Australian captain to retain the Ashes in England since 2001, averaged just 20 with 180 runs in the series with fears his career as captain may be over.

But, playing for Tasmania in the opening round of the Sheffield Shield, Paine answered his critics.

Coming in at 5/176 chasing Western Australia’s first innings score of 337, Paine hit 13 fours and a six in his 208-ball 121.

He brought up his century with a cut shot off Ashton Agar.

Here it is, the moment Aussie Test skipper Tim Paine brought up a brilliant 💯 in an important knock for Tasmania@MarshGlobal | #SheffieldShield pic.twitter.com/VEOZQfCT9t — cricket.com.au (@cricketcomau) October 12, 2019

It was his first century at first-class level since October 22 2006 when he finished the first day of a Shield clash on 119 not out as he went on to score 215.

While he has scored eight centuries at domestic one-day level and an ODI ton, he has yet to convert at Test level.

But surprisingly, Paine has the third highest Test average for an Australian wicketkeeper of all time at 31.45 in his 26 Test matches despite hitting just six fifties at Test level.

This is behind only Adam Gilchrist at 47.6 and 35.82 for Brad Haddin.

His output was slammed however as he had the lowest output for an Aussie wicketkeeper in a five-Test series since 1993.

It has not helped Paine avoid criticism with a debate raging in cricket circles as to who should replace the 34-year-old Tasmanian in the role.

Paine took over the captaincy when Steve Smith was removed in the midst of the ball tampering scandal and has been widely praised for leading Australia through one of its darkest periods.

But some Ashes criticism over some decisions and his batting effectiveness has some asking about the succession.

With Smith’s leadership ban ending next March and Paine seemingly closer to the end of his career than the start, the former skipper could once again take the reins.

There have also been some high profile Australian legends who have said it would not be the right call to bring Smith back.

Recently retired selector Greg Chappell said last week Smith might not even want the job.

“I don’t know whether he wants to,’’ Chappell told Brisbane’s RadioTAB last week.

“Should he? I don’t know. He is so important as a run-scorer and the responsibility of captaincy take their toll on the mental capabilities as well. I would almost rather have him place 100% of his mental capacity on making runs.

“He is always going to be there on the field for a captain to lean on and he is the sort of individual who will be reading the game the whole time. Even if you don’t talk to him. You only have to watch him for five minutes and you know what he is thinking about.”

Similarly, Australian coach Justin Langer told the ABC “honest conversations” will be needed, but that Paine could continue to build into the role.

“Tim Paine is doing a brilliant job at the moment as well. He’s been outstanding in his time as captain, so however long he wants to keep playing for is another thing,” he said.

“The beautiful thing about Tim Paine is that he knows he can get better. He can keep getting better, he will keep learning, and with his youthful enthusiasm, even as a senior player, he’s got lots of areas he can improve — that’s heartening for him and that’s heartening for us.

“But for the moment, he’s definitely doing a great job.”
description: Australian Test captain Tim Paine has let his bat do the talking after claims his time in the national set up were numbered.
